headline.main: Astronauts on Line For Live Discussion

results.snippet: Members of the crew of the space shuttle Endeavour will take part in a half-hour live discussion on The New York Times on America Online late tonight.    Three crew members -- Col. Jerry L. Ross and Dr. James H. Newman, both American mission...
results.lead_paragraph: Members of the crew of the space shuttle Endeavour will take part in a half-hour live discussion on The New York Times on America Online late tonight. Three crew members -- Col. Jerry L. Ross and Dr. James H. Newman, both American mission specialists, and Sergei Krikalev, a Russian astronaut -- will take questions during mission operations.

results.abstract: Space shuttle Endeavour is launched from Cape Canaveral with crew of six astronauts and the American-built space station component that they will attach to Russian component already in orbit; cost of assembling station and operating it for a decade is now put at $110 billion, of which $96 billion will be borne by US; editors of Sky and Telescope magazine criticize spending of such amounts of money on space station while funding of half-built superconducting supercollider has been stopped (M)

headline.main: Space Station's First Construction Crew Lifts Off Aboard the Shuttle

results.snippet: The planet's most daring construction job began today as the shuttle Endeavour carried into orbit six astronauts and the first American-built part of an international space station that is expected to cost more than $100 billion.    After a...
results.lead_paragraph: The planet's most daring construction job began today as the shuttle Endeavour carried into orbit six astronauts and the first American-built part of an international space station that is expected to cost more than $100 billion. After a last-minute alarm on the shuttle forced a postponement early Thursday, the launching went off flawlessly at 3:36 this morning, right on schedule. The night sky was clear, and the moon full. With a roar, Endeavour made its fiery ascent and briefly turned the Florida coastline from night to day. More than five minutes and 500 miles later, the spaceship's main engines could still be seen in the distance, twinkling like a new star.

results.abstract: Crew of space shuttle Endeavor hoists space station component from cargo bay; will attempt to attach it to Russian piece on Dec 6 (M)

headline.main: Shuttle Crew Surmounts First Challenge in Building Space Station

results.snippet: Endeavour's astronauts overcame their first hurdle today in building the international space station by hoisting the 25,000-pound Unity chamber from the shuttle cargo bay, with only an inch of clearance on each side.    A more difficult job awaits...
results.lead_paragraph: Endeavour's astronauts overcame their first hurdle today in building the international space station by hoisting the 25,000-pound Unity chamber from the shuttle cargo bay, with only an inch of clearance on each side. A more difficult job awaits them on Sunday, when they try to pluck a much larger Russian station component from orbit and attach it to the United States piece without a direct line of sight.

results.abstract: Andy Grundberg reviews books on photography: American Musicians: Photographs by Lee Friedlander; Vik Muniz: Seeing Is Believing by Vik Muniz; Julia Margaret Cameron's Women by Sylvia Wolf; Albert Renger-Patzsch: Photographer of Objectivity, edited by Ann and Jurgen Wilde and Thomas Weski; River of Colour: The India of Raghubir Singh by Singh; Hutterite: A World of Grace by Kristin Capp; Life Photographers: What They Saw by John Loengard; Hart Island by Melinda Hunt and Joel Sternfeld; and Disarming the Prairie by Terry Evans; drawings; photo (M)

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: RIVER OF COLOUR: THE INDIA OF RAGHUBIR SINGH (BOOK)

results.snippet: This season's bounty of photography books has an international flavor in both subject matter and source. Volumes surveying places far and near -- Algeria, India, Jerusalem, South Africa, New York City -- abound. That's par for the course, though;...
results.lead_paragraph: This season's bounty of photography books has an international flavor in both subject matter and source. Volumes surveying places far and near -- Algeria, India, Jerusalem, South Africa, New York City -- abound. That's par for the course, though; what's interesting is that American trade publishers are increasingly relying on offshore imprints for their titles. Art houses like Editions du Seuil in Paris, Phaidon in London and Scalo and Edition Stemmle in Zurich are the source of many of the most beautiful and interesting books this year, but you often have to look carefully to tell. The trend has a downside: for all the virtues of the photographs, the texts in these books can be stiffly translated and negligible in terms of scholarship. As for American specialized publishers, Arena Editions, now in its second year, continues to take chances with a volume on the emerging photo artist Vik Muniz, and Distributed Art Publishers adds to its publishing record a new and different Lee Friedlander book. Fans of more classic modern photography have to be content with the recycled images of some of their favorites -- books on the work of Margaret Bourke-White, Henri Cartier-Bresson, Man Ray and W. Eugene Smith are new this year but not especially novel. The nominees for the most interesting faded reputations to be brought back to light are Ellen Auerbach and Lottie Jacobi, two Bauhaus-era women whose careers are more interesting than the books devoted to them. Landscape photography also takes a new turn that is less skeptical than in recent years. But the expanding universe of photography books is a great deal larger than this suggests, as readers will discover soon enough on their holiday bookstore rounds.

headline.main: Ultimate High-Beam Job Site: 240 Miles Up

results.snippet: Their hardhats are helmets, their safety goggles are gold-coated visors and their boots are made of bulletproof fibers instead of leather, but they are nonetheless construction workers doing high-beam work.    Far above Earth, test pilots, engineers...
results.lead_paragraph: Their hardhats are helmets, their safety goggles are gold-coated visors and their boots are made of bulletproof fibers instead of leather, but they are nonetheless construction workers doing high-beam work. Far above Earth, test pilots, engineers and scientists have begun practicing the building trades as they tackle the mammoth job of assembling a space station at a truly remote site.

results.abstract: Space shuttle Endeavour astronauts, Col Jerry L Ross and Dr James H Newman, meticulously assemble dozens of power cables, connecting first two sections of international space station in Earth orbit; controllers later activate electrical power (M)

headline.main: With Space Station Parts Joined, Astronauts Make a Quick Start on Wiring Them Together

results.snippet: Two astronauts became electricians today as they left the shuttle Endeavour and meticulously assembled dozens of electrical cables, connecting the first two sections of the international space station.    After the astronauts completed the electrical...
results.lead_paragraph: Two astronauts became electricians today as they left the shuttle Endeavour and meticulously assembled dozens of electrical cables, connecting the first two sections of the international space station. After the astronauts completed the electrical connections, controllers signaled the Russian unit to turn on its power, and the American United module came alive at 10:49 P.M. Eastern time.

results.abstract: Astronauts Col Jerry L Ross and Dr James H Newman add communications antennas and remove unneeded equipment from exterior of space station in another space walk from shuttle Endeavour (M)

headline.main: 2 Astronauts Make 2d Space Walk to Install Antennas on Station

results.snippet: NASA's astronaut construction workers today added communications antennas and removed unneeded equipment from the exterior of the space station in another space walk from the shuttle Endeavour.    Col. Jerry L. Ross of the Air Force and Dr. James H....
results.lead_paragraph: NASA's astronaut construction workers today added communications antennas and removed unneeded equipment from the exterior of the space station in another space walk from the shuttle Endeavour. Col. Jerry L. Ross of the Air Force and Dr. James H. Newman, a physicist, completed a seven-hour space walk tonight after emerging from Endeavour's airlock earlier than planned, at 3:33 P.M. Eastern time. They accomplished all of their tasks, including improving the communications systems aboard the two station sections docked to the shuttle's cargo bay and freeing a stuck antenna.

results.abstract: First astronauts enter international space station, beginning an era that in a few years should lead to permanent human occupation of mammoth research outpost 250 miles above Earth; astronauts aboard space shuttle Endeavour, slowly working their way through series of hatches, enter first part of station at 2:54 Eastern time, emphasizing international nature of project (M)

headline.main: For the First Time, Astronauts Enter International Space Station

results.snippet: The first people entered the international space station today, beginning an era that in a few years should lead to permanent human occupation of the mammoth research outpost 250 miles above the Earth.    Astronauts aboard the space shuttle...
results.lead_paragraph: The first people entered the international space station today, beginning an era that in a few years should lead to permanent human occupation of the mammoth research outpost 250 miles above the Earth. Astronauts aboard the space shuttle Endeavour, slowly working their way through a series of hatches, entered the first part of the station at 2:54 P.M. Eastern time, emphasizing the international nature of the project.

results.abstract: Fernando Vargas, member of 1996 US Olympic boxing team, will fight International Boxing Federation junior middleweight champion Yory Boy Campas at Trump Taj Mahal in Atlantic City on Dec 12 (M)

headline.main: Will Vargas Be Up to the Challenge?

results.snippet: Fernando Vargas will be the second member of the 1996 United States Olympic boxing team to go for a world title when he faces Yory Boy Campas, the International Boxing Federation junior middleweight champion, tomorrow night at the Trump Taj Mahal in...
results.lead_paragraph: Fernando Vargas will be the second member of the 1996 United States Olympic boxing team to go for a world title when he faces Yory Boy Campas, the International Boxing Federation junior middleweight champion, tomorrow night at the Trump Taj Mahal in Atlantic City. The biggest question is whether this fight is too big a step for Vargas. Yes, Vargas is the No. 1 contender; yes, he is 14-0 and has knocked out all of his opponents. But he will be giving away 59 fights worth of experience to Campas (71-2).

results.snippet: The international space station, or at least the first part of it, opened for business. Robert D. Cabana, the American commander of the shuttle Endeavour, and a Russian astronaut, Sergei K. Krikalev, entered simultaneously to share the honor of being...
results.lead_paragraph: The international space station, or at least the first part of it, opened for business. Robert D. Cabana, the American commander of the shuttle Endeavour, and a Russian astronaut, Sergei K. Krikalev, entered simultaneously to share the honor of being the first humans aboard, emphasizing the international nature of the 16-nation, $60 billion venture to build the station over the next five years. WARREN E. LEARY

results.abstract: Interview with Eugenia Zukerman, flutist, television correspondent and writer, who will perform in Music at Hillwood series at Tilles Center, Brookville, NY; photo (M)¼

headline.main: A Force That Little Can Slow

results.snippet: ON ''CBS News Sunday Morning,'' the celebrated flutist and elegant correspondent Eugenia Zukerman was recently doing her weekly segment, this one about the pianist Jean-Yves Thibaudet. She said audiences loved him and he was popular with his peers;...
results.lead_paragraph: ON ''CBS News Sunday Morning,'' the celebrated flutist and elegant correspondent Eugenia Zukerman was recently doing her weekly segment, this one about the pianist Jean-Yves Thibaudet. She said audiences loved him and he was popular with his peers; she praised his technique, his way of conjuring colors. ''He brings out the hidden magic,'' she added. Most of this is true of Ms. Zukerman as well, with some extras. She writes books, directs a music festival, has made 19 recordings, gives recitals at the New York Public Library, has beaten a dangerous lung disease and still has what it takes to work for CBS -- and to perform at Tilles Center next Sunday.

results.snippet: Alejandra Castillo Lopez and Jeffrey Stuart Kluger were married yesterday at All Saints Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. Barbara Crafton officiated, and Rabbi Charles Lippman took part in the ceremony.    Mrs. Kluger is the production manager...
results.lead_paragraph: Alejandra Castillo Lopez and Jeffrey Stuart Kluger were married yesterday at All Saints Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. Barbara Crafton officiated, and Rabbi Charles Lippman took part in the ceremony. Mrs. Kluger is the production manager of the American Baby group of magazines at Primedia Inc. in New York. She is also an actress and a theater director; she directed a production of Shakespeare's ''Love's Labour's Lost'' last month at the American Globe Theater in New York.

results.abstract: David E Kelley, most prolific writer in television, has had string of successes with series that focus on characters who face tough choices and exhibit vulnerability of human condition; photos (M)

headline.main: From Arnie to 'Ally,' Capturing The Insecure Human Condition

results.snippet: JERRY SEINFELD put it as well as anybody. ''I mean,'' he said of David E. Kelley, ''this guy has done actual things.''    Mr. Kelley may be this decade's dean of the quality series, but when the Museum of Television and Radio in Los Angeles honored...
results.lead_paragraph: JERRY SEINFELD put it as well as anybody. ''I mean,'' he said of David E. Kelley, ''this guy has done actual things.'' Mr. Kelley may be this decade's dean of the quality series, but when the Museum of Television and Radio in Los Angeles honored him and Mr. Seinfeld on the same night two months ago, the speakers seemed to have trouble describing the essence of the Kelley genius as writer and producer.

results.abstract: Recently completed mission of space shuttle Endeavour was first in which crew members could routinely send and receive E-mail, using notebook computers and 'smart modems' developed by NASA and software largely supplied by Microsoft Corp; astronauts sent 620 messages, most of them personal (M)

headline.main: Compressed Data; Astronauts Get Mail; Microsoft Gets a Foothold

results.snippet: The E-mail revolution has breached another frontier -- space.    The space shuttle Endeavour finished a 12-day mission last Tuesday that was the first on which crew members could routinely send and receive E-mail, using notebook computers and ''smart...
results.lead_paragraph: The E-mail revolution has breached another frontier -- space. The space shuttle Endeavour finished a 12-day mission last Tuesday that was the first on which crew members could routinely send and receive E-mail, using notebook computers and ''smart modems'' developed by NASA engineers.

results.abstract: Article on Japanese fashion designer Issey Miyake focuses on 10-year retrospective, Issey Miyake: Making Things, at Cartier Foundation for Contemporary Art in Paris; photos (M)

headline.main: Easy to Pack, Harder to Understand

results.snippet: ISSEY MIYAKEISSEY MIYAKE is easy to pack. This is often the first thing a smart woman will tell you when you ask her why she wears Miyake's clothes. You can roll his dresses into a ball, they take up practically no room in your luggage, they weigh...
results.lead_paragraph: ISSEY MIYAKEISSEY MIYAKE is easy to pack. This is often the first thing a smart woman will tell you when you ask her why she wears Miyake's clothes. You can roll his dresses into a ball, they take up practically no room in your luggage, they weigh almost nothing, and when you arrive at your destination you just unroll and wear them. You can brown bag it around the world. In ''Issey Miyake: Making Things,'' a show of the last 10 years of the Japanese designer's work now on view at the Cartier Foundation for Contemporary Art in Paris, Miyake stages a witty play on the ease of traveling with his clothes. A huge wheel of black stretch fabric stands upright in the corner of one gallery. Partly unrolled across the floor, the fabric forms a continuous train that connects a tableau of five dresses, all made from the same material. It's a transformation scene, a metamorphosis in style. You could take the wheel anywhere, unroll a few dozen yards, snip, snip, et voila! Instant fashion show. (Flashbulbs not included.)
